awd_titl_txt: Algorithms for Large-Scale Nonlinear Eigenvalue Problems: Interpolation, Stability, Transient Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Dynamical systems are mathematical models of the changing world.  To understand such a model, one must describe how the system will evolve in time. Of interest is whether the solution grows with time, and whether the short-term behavior of the system is different from the behavior over a large-time window.  This project aims to develop tools to help scientists and engineers better analyze a challenging class of models in which the system's current rate-of-change is dictated by its configuration at some time in the recent past, models known as "delay systems."  Compelling examples come from biology, where this delay could correspond to gestation in a population, the incubation of a disease, or the time for a pill to dissolve.  In many important scenarios, highly accurate models require thousands or millions of variables.  This project will design high-performance computing algorithms to efficiently assess the behavior of such systems.

The research team will develop a new class of algorithms that are derived from interpolation techniques for model reduction of large-scale dynamical systems, for solving important large-scale nonlinear eigenvalue problems.  Nonlinear eigenvalue problems play an increasingly important role in many applications, including the stability analysis of delay differential equations.  Such problems pose a great challenge to computation: the number of eigenvalues is often infinite, even when the dimension of the problem is finite.   This project's interpolation-based techniques hold the promise of accurately modeling nonlinear operators over a broad region of the complex plane, resulting in algorithms that are both more efficient and more robust than existing methods.  Combining interpolation with structure-preserving subspace projection has the potential to approximate a much larger number of eigenvalues than possible with traditional methods.  To understand the performance of these new algorithms and to improve their speed, the project will also address convergence theory; for greater efficiency the project will explore inexact solution methods. Improved solvers for the nonlinear eigenvalue problem will inform development of the other two main aspects of this project: determination of critical stability transitions as a function of parameters (such as the time delays) in differential equations, and an enhanced understanding of the transient behavior of dynamical systems associated with nonlinear eigenvalue problems.  This project is expected to lead to substantial improvements in algorithms and analysis for the nonlinear eigenvalue problem and related stability questions.

por.por_cntn:
Many physical systems, like buildings and bridges, vibrate at special resonant frequencies, values that can be found by solving an "eigenvalue problem".  Some important scenarios -- such as a dynamical system whose behavior depends on its past state, or a vibrating network of strings coupled together, like a spider web -- lead to eigenvalue problems that have a challenging nonlinear structure.


This project has focused on numerical algorithms for computing eigenvalues, with a focus on these nonlinear eigenvalue problems.  A major outcome has been the creation of a new framework that expands a popular class of algorithms based on contour integration in the complex plane, methods that seek all the eigenvalues that fall within a designated region of the complex plane.  Our new framework derives from the recognition that these contour eigenvalue algorithms can be connected to "system identification" methods popular in engineering; furthermore, the framework leads to new algorithms ("single-point Loewner" and "multi-point Loewner" methods) for computing eigenvalues, which are novel even for conventional linear eigenvalue problems, as well as for the nonlinear problems that were the project's initial motivation.  The most expensive computational aspect of these new algorithms is shared with the existing ("Hankel") algorithm, meaning that an application scientist can readily test the old method and the new methods by blending the same data in different ways, taking the best approximation from several trial runs.  The proposed framework opens up exciting new avenues for algorithm designers to explore. 


In this new framework, several crucial questions arise: how many eigenvalues fall in the target region of the complex plane, and how robust are the eigenvalue approximations to inexactness in the underlying data (a fundamental aspect of contour integral methods)?  We have explored both these questions, studying how algorithm choices in the "multi-point Loewner" can clarify the number of eigenvalues in the target region, and computationally studying the sensitivity of the eigenvalue approximations using a tool called "pseudospectra".


In addition to this new algorithm for solving nonlinear eigenvalue problems, this project has addressed several other challenges in eigenvalue computations.  In some cases nonlinear eigenvalue problems depend on a parameter (say, the stiffness or damping of a filament in a spider web).  One would like a systematic way of developing approximations for a range of parameter values.  We thus propose a new algorithm (the "parametric Adaptive Antoulas Anderson", or p-AAA, method) based on a rational approximation to the nonlinear function of both the eigenvalue and the parameter.  This project has also studied a "polynomial preconditioning" method for solving large-scale conventional eigenvalue problems, which can take advantage of properties of high-performance computing.


We have also examined several interesting eigenvalue problems that demonstrate exotic properties.  We have demonstrated how one can achieve extreme short-term ("transient") growth in dynamical systems with delays that eventually decay with delays; because the underlying eigenvalue problem is nonlinear, it is possible to get such growth even for a system with just one variable.  (In linear systems, one needs multiple variables to see such growth.)  We have also studied an exotic conventional eigenvalue problem associated with a simplified physical model of twisted bilayer graphene. 


This project has involved numerous graduate students; related work will feature in the master's theses or PhD dissertations of five students.  The work has been presented in numerous national and international venues.  Key ideas grew out of an informal seminar on nonlinear eigenvalue problems conducted during the project's first year; elements of the project will be included in a graduate course to be taught in Spring 2022.  We anticipate that the new contour integral framework will open the door to additional algorithmic innovations that serve the needs of application scientists and engineers.
